Hey Ruqqies. I'm 17 and I'm going through a sort of mini-midlife crisis right now realizing I threw my entire childhood down the shitter, partly because of suppressed shame from an autism (mis)diagnosis. I'm stoned right now so if this is awkward then I'm sorry. I'll probably be deleting this when I wake up tomorrow.

I just wanted to talk about the diagnosis of Asperger's/autism and why I think it's really so commonly diagnosed, and how it's actually making kids worse.

To be clear, I do think Asperger's is a real disorder, but it's actually much rarer than it's made out to be. The problem isn't an increase in autism, but rather an increase in normal, socially awkward kids being misdiagnosed.

Alright, with that out of the way, let's get down to business.

Firstly, I *do* know what I'm doing. I know I'm weird, I could control it, but I simply don't. And I'm too embarrassed to admit it. I've been like this my whole life.  Rather than change, I simply suppressed my negative thoughts for most of my life.

When the Asperger's diagnosis came along in 2011, I was already confused about my emotions and too frightened to admit what was going on. All the sudden, I believed I couldn't improve no matter what, and I think I just gave up. I forgot all my emotions thinking they were a symptom of the problem rather than the problem itself.

I was homeschooled and extremely sheltered until 2019 when I tried to take the reigns and go to a public high school. There's a big culture shock leaving the small home I was stuck in for this big, complex real world. The fact that this wasn't considered by doctors is pretty surprising, but I probably never told them how I felt in the first place knowing how shy I was.

Since I was 6, I've had no joy in life. Maybe you could call it depression? I would. The world is dull, grey, numb, cold, and indifferent to me from my perspective. Nobody gives a shit about me. That's how I feel. My parents are strange and crazy enough and me, being homeschooled, had no way of realizing that (I actually did, but I think I ended up numbing myself to that early on to protect myself from the pain). My dad has always taught me to see the bad in everything. He's a miserable man.

I have always been extremely passive aggressive. I think I hate my parents, but hid it so deep within my head that it fell into my subconscious for a long time.

I've become so confused about my own emotions that I've lost any shred of personality I may have been able to develop, and have instead become lost in a false persona. I killed my soul, buried it, and built a new one, and I can't find a shovel to dig up the old one.

I think my parents have played a huge role in all this. I still have to keep my false, naive child persona around them rather than truly mature because I cannot live with what how I've acted and how I've made a fool of myself. I did try to change somewhat in 2019, but I just can't embrace normality until I can get away from everyone who knows my past. Imagine this kid (https://youtu.be/IORGuTdpSeo) amped up by about 3 times exactly (I am being literal), and that would be me until 15 and a half. And look at the way his parents act around him (I recently rediscovered my ability to read body language after I forgot it as a preteen after years of doing nothing but using the internet), and even how they talk about him. They clearly hate him, and maybe they themselves are suppressing their hatred for him. He and I are very similar.

Don't think it's all their fault though. I have always chosen vengeance, anger, and fear and the low route in general throughout my entire life. I am motivated completely by self interest because I'm too scared to see the objectifive reality and how much of a loser I really am. I am such a pussy to the point that I'm too afraid to learn from my own mistakes. Humiliation is terrifying to me.
But they did a lot to push me into this position of fearful rage.

My point is, I display many of the autistic symptoms almost by choice for some reason, and I know it's because I made so many terrible choices growing up. I've chosen to be a man child.

Now, considering how typical this is unexplainably with kids today, while also considering how different the social climate is, and the fact that there are no consistent differences in the high functioning autistic brain structure compared to a normal one, I find it hard to believe this is a true neurological disorder. Instead, I believe Asperger's/High functioning autism is a new phenomenon (Strange how that behavior was so rare in the Past compared to now) caused by a generation of awkward millennial (gen y and z) children having difficulties adapting to the new mid 21st century culture while battling memories of the less cynical late 20th/early 21st century. They are so afraid and distant that they don't even want to understand why they're afraid. 

There is no high functioning autism. Just unattractive (we do tend to be ugly) children with severe anxiety and a tendency towards extreme passive aggressiveness as well as roleplaying.

Rather than face these issues, the confused children are told it's out of their control and hopelessy choose to withdraw into a fantasy world.

For lower functioning cases, I don't have as much of a problem (there are noticeable differences in brain structure). As for high functioning autism, I think we're setting a generation up for a world of hurt.

We're not retards (no offense to the lower functioning). We're twisted and confused in our own goals and unwilling to change out of fear.

I'm so distant and separate from everyone in life that I'm not entirely in reality.

The last lines of Black Sabbath's song, "paranoid," really resonate with me. "And so as you hear these words telling you now of my state, I tell you to enjoy life I wish I could but it's too late."

It feels too late. 

But as an adult, I will be able to have a second chance. It's not over yet. I have another 10 years that have the potential to be infinitely better than the last.

Autism, at least in my case, is caused by a bad mindset I've adapted over the years. And I think that's the way it is for most people "on the spectrum" at this point.

Edit: Alright, I'm not gonna take this down. Thank you all for your support. It means a lot to me.

Hey Ruqqies. I'm 17 and I'm going through a sort of mini-midlife crisis right now realizing I threw my entire childhood down the shitter, partly because of suppressed shame from an autism (mis)diagnosis. I'm stoned right now so if this is awkward then I'm sorry. I'll probably be deleting this when I wake up tomorrow.

I just wanted to talk about the diagnosis of Asperger's/autism and why I think it's really so commonly diagnosed, and how it's actually making kids worse.

To be clear, I do think Asperger's is a real disorder, but it's actually much rarer than it's made out to be. The problem isn't an increase in autism, but rather an increase in normal, socially awkward kids being misdiagnosed.

Alright, with that out of the way, let's get down to business.

Firstly, I *do* know what I'm doing. I know I'm weird, I could control it, but I simply don't. And I'm too embarrassed to admit it. I've been like this my whole life.  Rather than change, I simply suppressed my negative thoughts for most of my life.

When the Asperger's diagnosis came along in 2011, I was already confused about my emotions and too frightened to admit what was going on. All the sudden, I believed I couldn't improve no matter what, and I think I just gave up. I forgot all my emotions thinking they were a symptom of the problem rather than the problem itself.

I was homeschooled and extremely sheltered until 2019 when I tried to take the reigns and go to a public high school. There's a big culture shock leaving the small home I was stuck in for this big, complex real world. The fact that this wasn't considered by doctors is pretty surprising, but I probably never told them how I felt in the first place knowing how shy I was.

Since I was 6, I've had no joy in life. Maybe you could call it depression? I would. The world is dull, grey, numb, cold, and indifferent to me from my perspective. Nobody gives a shit about me. That's how I feel. My parents are strange and crazy enough and me, being homeschooled, had no way of realizing that (I actually did, but I think I ended up numbing myself to that early on to protect myself from the pain). My dad has always taught me to see the bad in everything. He's a miserable man.

I have always been extremely passive aggressive. I think I hate my parents, but hid it so deep within my head that it fell into my subconscious for a long time.

I've become so confused about my own emotions that I've lost any shred of personality I may have been able to develop, and have instead become lost in a false persona. I killed my soul, buried it, and built a new one, and I can't find a shovel to dig up the old one.

I think my parents have played a huge role in all this. I still have to keep my false, naive child persona around them rather than truly mature because I cannot live with what how I've acted and how I've made a fool of myself. I did try to change somewhat in 2019, but I just can't embrace normality until I can get away from everyone who knows my past. Imagine this kid (https://youtu.be/IORGuTdpSeo) amped up by about 3 times exactly (I am being literal), and that would be me until 15 and a half. And look at the way his parents act around him (I recently rediscovered my ability to read body language after I forgot it as a preteen after years of doing nothing but using the internet), and even how they talk about him. They clearly hate him, and maybe they themselves are suppressing their hatred for him. He and I are very similar.

Don't think it's all their fault though. I have always chosen vengeance, anger, and fear and the low route in general throughout my entire life. I am motivated completely by self interest because I'm too scared to see the objectifive reality and how much of a loser I really am. I am such a pussy to the point that I'm too afraid to learn from my own mistakes. Humiliation is terrifying to me.
But they did a lot to push me into this position of fearful rage.

My point is, I display many of the autistic symptoms almost by choice for some reason, and I know it's because I made so many terrible choices growing up. I've chosen to be a man child.

Now, considering how typical this is unexplainably with kids today, while also considering how different the social climate is, and the fact that there are no consistent differences in the high functioning autistic brain structure compared to a normal one, I find it hard to believe this is a true neurological disorder. Instead, I believe Asperger's/High functioning autism is a new phenomenon (Strange how that behavior was so rare in the Past compared to now) caused by a generation of awkward millennial (gen y and z) children having difficulties adapting to the new mid 21st century culture while battling memories of the less cynical late 20th/early 21st century. They are so afraid and distant that they don't even want to understand why they're afraid. 

There is no high functioning autism. Just unattractive (we do tend to be ugly) children with severe anxiety and a tendency towards extreme passive aggressiveness as well as roleplaying.

Rather than face these issues, the confused children are told it's out of their control and hopelessy choose to withdraw into a fantasy world.

For lower functioning cases, I don't have as much of a problem (there are noticeable differences in brain structure). As for high functioning autism, I think we're setting a generation up for a world of hurt.

We're not retards (no offense to the lower functioning). We're twisted and confused in our own goals and unwilling to change out of fear.

I'm so distant and separate from everyone in life that I'm not entirely in reality.

The last lines of Black Sabbath's song, "paranoid," really resonate with me. "And so as you hear these words telling you now of my state, I tell you to enjoy life I wish I could but it's too late."

It feels too late. 

But as an adult, I will be able to have a second chance. It's not over yet. I have another 10 years that have the potential to be infinitely better than the last.

Autism, at least in my case, is caused by a bad mindset I've adapted over the years. And I think that's the way it is for most people "on the spectrum" at this point.

Edit: Alright, I'm not gonna take this down. Thank you all for your support. It means a lot to me.

Hey Ruqqies. I'm 17 and I'm going through a sort of mini-midlife crisis right now realizing I threw my entire childhood down the shitter, partly because of suppressed shame from an autism (mis)diagnosis. I'm stoned right now so if this is awkward then I'm sorry. I'll probably be deleting this when I wake up tomorrow.

I just wanted to talk about the diagnosis of Asperger's/autism and why I think it's really so commonly diagnosed, and how it's actually making kids worse.

To be clear, I do think Asperger's is a real disorder, but it's actually much rarer than it's made out to be. The problem isn't an increase in autism, but rather an increase in normal, socially awkward kids being misdiagnosed.

Alright, with that out of the way, let's get down to business.

Firstly, I *do* know what I'm doing. I know I'm weird, I could control it, but I simply don't. And I'm too embarrassed to admit it. I've been like this my whole life.  Rather than change, I simply suppressed my negative thoughts for most of my life.

When the Asperger's diagnosis came along in 2011, I was already confused about my emotions and too frightened to admit what was going on. All the sudden, I believed I couldn't improve no matter what, and I think I just gave up. I forgot all my emotions thinking they were a symptom of the problem rather than the problem itself.

I was homeschooled and extremely sheltered until 2019 when I tried to take the reigns and go to a public high school. There's a big culture shock leaving the small home I was stuck in for this big, complex real world. The fact that this wasn't considered by doctors is pretty surprising, but I probably never told them how I felt in the first place knowing how shy I was.

Since I was 6, I've had no joy in life. Maybe you could call it depression? I would. The world is dull, grey, numb, cold, and indifferent to me from my perspective. Nobody gives a shit about me. That's how I feel. My parents are strange and crazy enough and me, being homeschooled, had no way of realizing that (I actually did, but I think I ended up numbing myself to that early on to protect myself from the pain). My dad has always taught me to see the bad in everything. He's a miserable man.

I have always been extremely passive aggressive. I think I hate my parents, but hid it so deep within my head that it fell into my subconscious for a long time.

I've become so confused about my own emotions that I've lost any shred of personality I may have been able to develop, and have instead become lost in a false persona. I killed my soul, buried it, and built a new one, and I can't find a shovel to dig up the old one.

I think my parents have played a huge role in all this. I still have to keep my false, naive child persona around them rather than truly mature because I cannot live with what how I've acted and how I've made a fool of myself. I did try to change somewhat in 2019, but I just can't embrace normality until I can get away from everyone who knows my past. Imagine this kid (https://youtu.be/IORGuTdpSeo) amped up by about 3 times exactly (I am being literal), and that would be me until 15 and a half. And look at the way his parents act around him (I recently rediscovered my ability to read body language after I forgot it as a preteen after years of doing nothing but using the internet), and even how they talk about him. They clearly hate him, and maybe they themselves are suppressing their hatred for him. He and I are very similar.

Don't think it's all their fault though. I have always chosen vengeance, anger, and fear and the low route in general throughout my entire life. I am motivated completely by self interest because I'm too scared to see the objectifive reality and how much of a loser I really am. I am such a pussy to the point that I'm too afraid to learn from my own mistakes. Humiliation is terrifying to me.
But they did a lot to push me into this position of fearful rage.

My point is, I display many of the autistic symptoms almost by choice for some reason, and I know it's because I made so many terrible choices growing up. I've chosen to be a man child.

Now, considering how typical this is unexplainably with kids today, while also considering how different the social climate is, and the fact that there are no consistent differences in the high functioning autistic brain structure compared to a normal one, I find it hard to believe this is a true neurological disorder. Instead, I believe Asperger's/High functioning autism is a new phenomenon (Strange how that behavior was so rare in the Past compared to now) caused by a generation of awkward millennial (gen y and z) children having difficulties adapting to the new mid 21st century culture while battling memories of the less cynical late 20th/early 21st century. They are so afraid and distant that they don't even want to understand why they're afraid. 

There is no high functioning autism. Just unattractive (we do tend to be ugly) children with severe anxiety and a tendency towards extreme passive aggressiveness as well as roleplaying.

Rather than face these issues, the confused children are told it's out of their control and hopelessy choose to withdraw into a fantasy world.

For lower functioning cases, I don't have as much of a problem (there are noticeable differences in brain structure). As for high functioning autism, I think we're setting a generation up for a world of hurt.

We're not retards (no offense to the lower functioning). We're twisted and confused in our own goals and unwilling to change out of fear.

I'm so distant and separate from everyone in life that I'm not entirely in reality.

The last lines of Black Sabbath's song, "paranoid," really resonate with me. "And so as you hear these words telling you now of my state, I tell you to enjoy life I wish I could but it's too late."

It feels too late. 

But as an adult, I will be able to have a second chance. It's not over yet. I have another 10 years that have the potential to be infinitely better than the last.

Autism, at least in my case, is caused by a bad mindset I've adapted over the years. And I think that's the way it is for most people "on the spectrum" at this point.

Edit: Alright, I'm not gonna take this down. Thank you all for your support. It means a lot to me.

> Adam certainly had a good understanding of God and his expectations, especially if he had lived hundreds of years by that point, in which case, he is a scripture. You can go to him to know what God would say about this or that, or to better understand what the will of God is. Where can i go for that? Certainly no churches have helped me in this pursuit.

Where do you think Adam got his understanding? What's to prevent the same from happening with anyone else?

> The Holy Spirit may guide me, but how can a solid foundation be built without a reliable concrete source?

This is, at its root, a lack of faith. Sometimes you will make wrong judgements, but so did the writers of those books, and that's why they also contain errors, and they actually condemn each other more than you have been led to believe (Actually, you have to make more of your own judgements relying solely on written text. Like how a law says what it says, but the judge who decides its meaning is infinitely more important). But you can't trust the spirit, so you put your trust in a book instead. Everyone has that longing for something to look up to, and when they reject it they try to fill it with something else (idolatry), and in many cases it's the Bible.

> I mean, how do you decide what has been altered? Do you just pick and choose what sounds right to you and toss out the rest?

There's actually more room for cherry picking as it stands, because you have to pick one set of teachings that you like and find a clever way to interpret away the contradicting ones. Interestingly most who do this rarely opt for what Jesus taught.

> But if we could innately know what is right or wrong then why are we so much better at justifying wrong behavior than right?

Because we choose to, and reject the spirit. I cannot say that sola scriptura abiding Christians are any better than a non-believer at making moral judgements, they only make different ones.

> There has to be some reliable foundation that we can compare ourselves to.

The spirit is reliable. The trouble with this is that humans want defined sets of rules, they crave structure and order, otherwise they feel insecure. Most will even tolerate a dictatorship if it satisfies this craving. Thus raw moral principles and acting on a case by case basis, and especially communication with a higher power, is not attractive to most. It's also not as easy to judge others by, which creatures are also hardwired to want because getting others harmed or punished reduces competition and increases their own chances of survival. And it doesn't allow for loopholes.

First I suppose a short summary of YOLO would be good, for anyone who hasn't heard the phrase yet. I suspect that YOLO itself is foreign to some, but I'm confident every culture throughout all time has had people of a similar mindset of life, and it was a popular phrase when I was growing up.

YOLO stands for 'You Only Live Once,' and often serves as a call to sin, or justification for doing something wicked or even just stupid. Before you hear someone about to do something stupid or destructive, you were apt to hear them yell YOLO. If you don't understand what I'm getting at, once you read the passage then I think you will understand. 

If any similar "catchphrases" come to mind as you read this, or if you have witnessed such reasoning yourself, please leave a comment about it.

The following excerpt is from the book 'Wisdom of Solomon,' sometimes referred to as the 'Book of Wisdom,' and the secular consensus is that it was not written by Solomon, but rather by others in ~50 B.C. who held Solomon's wisdom in high regard; and was not meant as a forgery, but written in his honor. 

This book was highly regarded by most early church fathers and even included in the original publication of the KJV bible, but most also agree that it should not be considered scripture, especially not upon which doctrine can be established. There are some yellow flags that are hard to reconcile with the rest of the bible, but I have a really hard time imagining that this was written by someone who wasn't influenced by God; and it has done a lot to motivate me towards the pursuit of righteousness. There is even what appears to be a prophecy of Christ's death, written well before he was manifested in the flesh.

Without further ado: the second chapter of the book of wisdom. (Put into paragraph form by me, with slight adjustments for fluidity, mostly semi-colon and commas and colons, with only a few words changed):

>For the ungodly said, reasoning with themselves, but not aright: Our life is short and tedious, and in the death of a man there is no remedy; neither was there any man known to have returned from the grave. For we are born at all adventure: and we shall be hereafter as though we had never been - for the breath in our nostrils is as smoke, and a little spark in the moving of our heart; which being extinguished, our body shall be turned into ashes, and our spirit shall vanish as the soft air, and our name shall be forgotten in time, and no man shall have our works in remembrance, and our life shall pass away as the trace of a cloud, and shall be dispersed as a mist, that is driven away with the beams of the sun, and overcome with the heat thereof.

>For our time is a very shadow that passes away; and after our end there is no returning: for it is fast sealed, so that no man comes again. Come on therefore, let us enjoy the good things that are present: and let us speedily use the creatures like as in youth. Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and ointments: and let no flower of the spring pass by us; let us crown ourselves with rosebuds, before they be withered; let none of us go without his part of our voluptuousness; let us leave tokens of our joyfulness in every place: for this is our portion, and our lot is this.

>Let us oppress the poor righteous man, let us not spare the widow, nor reverence the ancient gray hairs of the aged. Let our strength be the law of justice: for that which is feeble is found to be nothing worth. Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings; he upbraids us for our offending the law, and to our infamy he objects to our transgressing of our education.

>He professes to have the knowledge of God: and he calls himself the child of the Lord. He was made to reprove our thoughts; he is grievous unto us even to behold, for his life is not like other men's; his ways are of another fashion. We are esteemed of him as counterfeits; he abstains from our ways as from filthiness. He pronounces the end of the just to be blessed, and makes his boast that God is his father.

>Let us see if his words be true, and let us prove what shall happen in his end. For if the just man be the son of God, He will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies. Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience. Let us condemn him with a shameful death, for by his own saying he shall be respected.

>Such things they did imagine, and were deceived: for their own wickedness had blinded them. As for the mysteries of God, they knew them not; neither hoped they for the wages of righteousness, nor discerned a reward for blameless souls. For God created man to be immortal, and made him to be an image of his own eternity. Nevertheless, through envy of the devil came death into the world; and they that hold to his side do find it.

First I suppose a short summary of YOLO would be good, for anyone who hasn't heard the phrase yet. I suspect that YOLO itself is foreign to some, but I'm confident every culture throughout all time has had people of a similar mindset of life, and it was a popular phrase when I was growing up.

YOLO stands for 'You Only Live Once,' and often serves as a call to sin, or justification for doing something wicked or even just stupid. Before you hear someone about to do something stupid or destructive, you were apt to hear them yell YOLO. If you don't understand what I'm getting at, once you read the passage then I think you will understand. 

If any similar "catchphrases" come to mind as you read this, or if you have witnessed such reasoning yourself, please leave a comment about it.

The following excerpt is from the book 'Wisdom of Solomon,' sometimes referred to as the 'Book of Wisdom,' and the secular consensus is that it was not written by Solomon, but rather by others in ~50 B.C. who held Solomon's wisdom in high regard; and was not meant as a forgery, but written in his honor. 

This book was highly regarded by most early church fathers and even included in the original publication of the KJV bible, but most also agree that it should not be considered scripture, especially not upon which doctrine can be established. There are some yellow flags that are hard to reconcile with the rest of the bible, but I have a really hard time imagining that this was written by someone who wasn't influenced by God; and it has done a lot to motivate me towards the pursuit of righteousness. There is even what appears to be a prophecy of Christ's death, written well before he was manifested in the flesh.

Without further ado: the second chapter of the book of wisdom. (Put into paragraph form by me, with slight adjustments for fluidity, mostly semi-colon and commas and colons, with only a few words changed):

>For the ungodly said, reasoning with themselves, but not aright: Our life is short and tedious, and in the death of a man there is no remedy; neither was there any man known to have returned from the grave. For we are born at all adventure: and we shall be hereafter as though we had never been - for the breath in our nostrils is as smoke, and a little spark in the moving of our heart; which being extinguished, our body shall be turned into ashes, and our spirit shall vanish as the soft air, and our name shall be forgotten in time, and no man shall have our works in remembrance, and our life shall pass away as the trace of a cloud, and shall be dispersed as a mist, that is driven away with the beams of the sun, and overcome with the heat thereof.

>For our time is a very shadow that passes away; and after our end there is no returning: for it is fast sealed, so that no man comes again. Come on therefore, let us enjoy the good things that are present: and let us speedily use the creatures like as in youth. Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and ointments: and let no flower of the spring pass by us; let us crown ourselves with rosebuds, before they be withered; let none of us go without his part of our voluptuousness; let us leave tokens of our joyfulness in every place: for this is our portion, and our lot is this.

>Let us oppress the poor righteous man, let us not spare the widow, nor reverence the ancient gray hairs of the aged. Let our strength be the law of justice: for that which is feeble is found to be nothing worth. Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings; he upbraids us for our offending the law, and to our infamy he objects to our transgressing of our education.

>He professes to have the knowledge of God: and he calls himself the child of the Lord. He was made to reprove our thoughts; he is grievous unto us even to behold, for his life is not like other men's; his ways are of another fashion. We are esteemed of him as counterfeits; he abstains from our ways as from filthiness. He pronounces the end of the just to be blessed, and makes his boast that God is his father.

>Let us see if his words be true, and let us prove what shall happen in his end. For if the just man be the son of God, He will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies. Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience. Let us condemn him with a shameful death, for by his own saying he shall be respected.

>Such things they did imagine, and were deceived: for their own wickedness had blinded them. As for the mysteries of God, they knew them not; neither hoped they for the wages of righteousness, nor discerned a reward for blameless souls. For God created man to be immortal, and made him to be an image of his own eternity. Nevertheless, through envy of the devil came death into the world; and they that hold to his side do find it.

Posts can be made questioning the validity/veracity of the bible itself, but in any conversation wherein the topic itself is not the legitimacy of the bible, then it is assumed to be correct and factual. How else can any foundation be established except if the bible is a source of truth? Is man's opinion above God's word?

To the greatest extent possible i will avoid all forms of censorship, even spam would ideally be dealt with by down-voting rather than deleting. There is no restriction on post-type (you can post whatever you want) aside from the obvious nono's like porn, spam, calls to violence, etc..

First I suppose a short summary of YOLO would be good, for anyone who hasn't heard the phrase yet. I suspect that YOLO itself is foreign to some, but I'm confident every culture throughout all time has had people of a similar mindset of life, and it was a popular phrase when I was growing up.

YOLO stands for 'You Only Live Once,' and often serves as a call to sin, or justification for doing something wicked or even just stupid. Before you hear someone about to do something stupid or destructive, you were apt to hear them yell YOLO. If you don't understand what I'm getting at, once you read the passage then I think you will understand. 

If any similar "catchphrases" come to mind as you read this, or if you have witnessed such reasoning yourself, please leave a comment about it.

The following excerpt is from the book 'Wisdom of Solomon,' sometimes referred to as the 'Book of Wisdom,' and the secular consensus is that it was not written by Solomon, but rather by others in ~50 B.C. who held Solomon's wisdom in high regard; and was not meant as a forgery, but written in his honor. 

This book was highly regarded by most early church fathers and even included in the original publication of the KJV bible, but most also agree that it should not be considered scripture, especially not upon which doctrine can be established. There are some yellow flags that are hard to reconcile with the rest of the bible, but I have a really hard time imagining that this was written by someone who wasn't influenced by God; and it has done a lot to motivate me towards the pursuit of righteousness. There is even what appears to be a prophecy of Christ's death, written well before he was manifested in the flesh.

Without further ado: the second chapter of the book of wisdom. (Put into paragraph form by me, with slight adjustments for fluidity, mostly semi-colon and commas and colons, with only a few words changed):

>For the ungodly said, reasoning with themselves, but not aright: Our life is short and tedious, and in the death of a man there is no remedy; neither was there any man known to have returned from the grave. For we are born at all adventure: and we shall be hereafter as though we had never been - for the breath in our nostrils is as smoke, and a little spark in the moving of our heart; which being extinguished, our body shall be turned into ashes, and our spirit shall vanish as the soft air, and our name shall be forgotten in time, and no man shall have our works in remembrance, and our life shall pass away as the trace of a cloud, and shall be dispersed as a mist, that is driven away with the beams of the sun, and overcome with the heat thereof.

>For our time is a very shadow that passes away; and after our end there is no returning: for it is fast sealed, so that no man comes again. Come on therefore, let us enjoy the good things that are present: and let us speedily use the creatures like as in youth. Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and ointments: and let no flower of the spring pass by us; let us crown ourselves with rosebuds, before they be withered; let none of us go without his part of our voluptuousness; let us leave tokens of our joyfulness in every place: for this is our portion, and our lot is this.

>Let us oppress the poor righteous man, let us not spare the widow, nor reverence the ancient gray hairs of the aged. Let our strength be the law of justice: for that which is feeble is found to be nothing worth. Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings; he upbraids us for our offending the law, and to our infamy he objects to our transgressing of our education.

>He professes to have the knowledge of God: and he calls himself the child of the Lord. He was made to reprove our thoughts; he is grievous unto us even to behold, for his life is not like other men's; his ways are of another fashion. We are esteemed of him as counterfeits; he abstains from our ways as from filthiness. He pronounces the end of the just to be blessed, and makes his boast that God is his father.

>Let us see if his words be true, and let us prove what shall happen in his end. For if the just man be the son of God, He will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies. Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience. Let us condemn him with a shameful death, for by his own saying he shall be respected.

>Such things they did imagine, and were deceived: for their own wickedness had blinded them. As for the mysteries of God, they knew them not; neither hoped they for the wages of righteousness, nor discerned a reward for blameless souls. For God created man to be immortal, and made him to be an image of his own eternity. Nevertheless, through envy of the devil came death into the world; and they that hold to his side do find it.

Source text:

https://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/k/kjv/kjv-idx?type=DIV1&byte=3849598
